{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3562873,"name":"Gavin Precurato","username":"Gavo9649","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gavo9649/{size}/181077_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T14:04:39.388Z","cooked":"

This is our team’s first year using the CTRE generated swerve code, and we haven’t been able to figure out how to get it to drive robot centric. I’ve tried a couple things like using setControl instead of applyRequest but that didn’t seem to work, we were most likely just calling it the wrong way but I’m not sure.

When the left bumper is held it should drive robot centric, then go back to field oriented when it’s not pressed.

Also if anyone knows how to implement this it would be greatly appreciated: When another button is held like the right bumper, it scales all the inputs of the drivetrain down to a certain percentage to allow for fine movements. (We tried to add this but I think I see why it isn’t working: the default command is only updated once and isn’t updated again to reflect if the state of the bumper has changed)

Here’s our code. Thank you!

[ Updated: Sorry… I did it the wrong way…. This should be closer!]

You need to declare a robot centric swerve request.

    public final SwerveRequest.robotCentric robotDrive = new SwerveRequest.RobotCentric()
            .withDeadband(MaxSpeed * 0.1).withRotationalDeadband(MaxAngularRate * 0.1) // Add a 10% deadband
            .withDriveRequestType(DriveRequestType.OpenLoopVoltage); // Use open-loop control for drive motors

And then use it… my syntax will be close, but likely not perfect…

pilot.leftBumper().whileTrue(
                drivetrain.applyRequest(() -> robotDrive
 
                        .withVelocityX(-pilot.getLeftY()) // Drive forward with negative Y(forward)
                        .withVelocityY(-pilot.getLeftX()) // Drive left with negative X (left)
                        .withRotationalRate(-pilot.getRightX())
","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":3,"updated_at":"2025-03-20T14:35:46.130Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":45,"readers_count":44,"score":14.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":496324,"topic_slug":"robot-centric-drive-using-ctre-swerve-code","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":36169,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Software Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/robot-centric-drive-using-ctre-swerve-code/496324/2","custom_user_title":"Software Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3562908,"name":"Kevin Furlong","username":"dewmaster","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/49beb7/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T14:43:03.584Z","cooked":"

You already have a RobotCentric SwerveRequest defined, you just need to apply it.

pilot.rightBumper().whileTrue(
	drivetrain.applyRequest(() ->
                driveRobotCentric.withVelocityX(-pilot.getLeftY() * MaxSpeed) // Drive forward with negative Y (forward)
                    .withVelocityY(-pilot.getLeftX() * MaxSpeed) // Drive left with negative X (left)
                    .withRotationalRate(-pilot.getRightX() * MaxAngularRate) // Drive counterclockwise with negative X (left)
            )
);
